FacilityName: Rich Products Corporation- Union City Facility

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
0 Whipple Road in the City of Union City, Alameda County, California and is situated in a mixed light industrial/residential area. The Facility occupies an approximately 190,000 square-foot structure that is located on 9.15 acres of land. The Facility was originally built in 1965 and was refurbished by RPC in 2012 to accommodate operations. The Facility operates normally 5 to 7 days per week, 24 hours per day, depending on product demands.

The Facility manufactures doughnuts, which are frozen for shipment. The Facility's North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS) code is 31141 (Frozen Food Manufacturing)

As part of the refrigeration system to freeze the doughnuts for shipment, the Facility handles quantities of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance/highly hazardous chemical as defined in the USEPA's CAPP; OSHA's PSM standard; CalOES' CalARP program, and the Cal/OSHA PSM standard in an amount exceeding the regulatory threshold  for anhydrous ammonia in a single process, i.e., the Site's refrigeration system. The Facility is registered to Program Level 3 under both the CAPP and CalARP programs.

The anhydrous ammonia is contained in various vessels, accumulators, piping, and heat exchangers throughout the refrigeration system. The Facility's engine room houses the majority of the refrigeration machinery.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION

While there are few long-term environmental consequences to ammonia use, it can present health hazards if handled improperly. RPC has developed a comprehensive safety program in compliance with OSHA and EPA requirements to ensure the responsible management of the ammonia onsite (the Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program, respectively). All refrigeration Associates receive operator training, safe work practices training and training on the standard operating procedures (SOPs). Safety meetings are conducted to further protect Associates and the community as a whole.

The Facility's prevent

ion program is designed to inform all Associates of the hazards of ammonia, procedures for the safe use of ammonia, and the steps taken for the safety of Associates and the community in the event of a release or spill. 

The Facility endeavors to eliminate accidents and health hazards to Associates, customers, and the community by having procedures in place to provide Associates educational training, safe working conditions, and the means to increase awareness of potential dangers both on and off the job. RPC's objective is to prevent unwanted releases of ammonia into locations that could potentially expose Associates and others to serious hazards. An effective program requires a systematic approach to evaluating the entire system. Workplace and process safety are major concerns to management and Associates alike. The prevention and mitigation of unwanted releases of ammonia into locations that could expose Associates and the community to serious hazards is of primary concern.

The Facility has incorporated many safety features in the design of the ammonia refrigeration system to prevent system failures and to mitigate potential releases. The predominant safety concern with closed-loop ammonia systems is an inadvertent buildup of pressure exceeding pressure ratings or capacities of equipment due to ammonia expansion. The Facility's ammonia system is continuously monitored by automated control systems that shutdown pump and the components if deviations from normal operating conditions occur. Further, the system is equipped with pressure relief valves on all pressure vessels and most, if not all, additional locations within the ammonia system where ammonia could become trapped.

RPC considers the health and safety of each Associate as its most important responsibility. It is our policy to provide a healthy and safe work environment. This facility follows operating practices that safeguard all associates and result in safe working conditions while maintaining eff

icient operations.

Safety is the responsibility of all Associates. Each associate is expected to comply with the requirements of RPC's Standards for Safety Performance. Management is responsible for the implementation, communication, documentation, and necessary training. The Associate is responsible for implementation, communication, and practices of the program. Management is committed to maintain a high level of interest in health and safety throughout this facility. This commitment extends to the associates and their involvement in preventing accidents.

RPC has established its Health and Safety Program to insure that:

¿	Associates work in a healthy and safe environment.
¿	Associates are trained on safe work practices.
¿	Associates practice safe work habits.
¿	Management and associates are both involved in the program.
¿	There is constant communication between all Associates on safety issues.
¿	Compliance with all regulatory agencies is maintained.

Major safety features at the Facility include:

¿	Installation of Ammonia leak detectors in processing areas and the engine room
¿	Remote emergency shutdown switches for the refrigeration system
¿	Fire sprinklers throughout the Facility
¿	Component specific safety shutdowns of the refrigeration system
¿	Water-filled diffusion tank to treat accidental release of ammonia through pressure relief valves, and
¿	A proprietary Refrigeration Energy Management System (REMS) computer monitoring system.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Since RPC commence operations, there have been no accidental releases.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Facility is equipped with an emergency warning system. Alarms are placed throughout the Facility to alarm personnel of an emergency relating to the accidental release of ammonia or other emergencies that may be encountered. RPC has developed specific procedures to be followed in the event of release. These procedures include evacuation of personnel, notificatio

n of authorities and actions to be taken to stop or mitigate the emergency if it is safe to do so.

Plant personnel have received emergency response training as outlined in OSHA's HAZWOPER regulation 29 CFR 1910.120 and other various rules and regulations.

The Alameda County Fire Department has visited the facility to review the process operations, safety systems and discuss emergency response coordination.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Facility recognizes that the implementation of this program is a continuous process for evaluating, monitoring and improving anhydrous ammonia handling operation at the Facility. As such, the prevention program will evolve as RPC continues their ongoing focus and dedication of risk minimization and safety improvement for the employees and the surrounding community.
